required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Total Hip Arthoplastry Revision by Dual-mobility Acetabular Cup Cemented in a Metal Reinforcement
clinical_study.official_title: Total Hip Arthoplastry Revision by Dual-mobility Acetabular Cup Cemented in a Metal Reinforcement: A 62 Case Series at a Minimum 5 Years Follow-up

brief_summary.textblock:
Total hip arthroplasty (THA) requires bone reconstruction in case of severe acetabular injury, with risk of dislocation, especially postoperatively. Dual-mobility cups have proved effective in preventing dislocation in THA revision for instability, but their behavior when cemented in a metal reinforcement has been little studied.
The present study assessed results for a dual-mobility cup cemented in a metal reinforcement, in terms of aseptic loosening and postoperative instability.
A single-center continuous series of 62 patients receiving such an assembly in THA revision was assessed retrospectively at a minimum 5 years' follow-up.

detailed_description.textblock:
Total hip arthroplasty (THA) requires bone reconstruction in case of severe acetabular injury, with risk of dislocation, especially postoperatively. Dual-mobility cups have proved effective in preventing dislocation in THA revision for instability, but their behavior when cemented in a metal reinforcement has been little studied.
The present study assessed results for a dual-mobility cup cemented in a metal reinforcement, in terms of aseptic loosening and postoperative instability.
A single-center continuous series of 62 patients receiving such an assembly in THA revision was assessed retrospectively at a minimum 5 years' follow-up. Failure due to aseptic loosening or instability and implant survival at last follow-up were analyzed.

primary_outcome.measure: dual-mobility cup cemented (effectiveness in terms of aseptic loosening)
primary_outcome.description: The objective of the present study is to evaluate the most effective type of assembly , dual-mobility cup cemented in a metal reinforcement, in terms of aseptic loosening in the prevention of dislocation during the revision of the total hip arthroplasty (THA)

intervention.description: A single-center continuous series of 62 patients receiving such an assembly in THA revision was assessed retrospectively at a minimum 5 years' follow-up. Failure due to aseptic loosening or instability and implant survival at last follow-up were analyzed.

study_pop.textblock: 62 patients receiving such an assembly in THA revision was assessed retrospectively at a minimum 5 years' follow-up. Failure due to aseptic loosening or instability and implant survival at last follow-up were analyzed.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients between 19 and 84 years
- patients receiving such an assembly in THA revision
Exclusion Criteria:
- <19years
- > 94 years
